content.description:
CRIMES RECORDED IN COURT SESSIONS OF THE RELIGIOUS COURT IN CALVINIST NÎMES, FRANCE, 1561–1563 AND 1578–1583 CATEGORY OF OFFENSE 1561–1563 1578–1583 Total 1. Disputes and quarrels 256 (53%) 560 (50%) 816 (50%) 2. Behavioral offenses (dancing, swearing, frequenting taverns, etc.) 39 (8%) 256 (22%) 295 (18%) 3. Ecclesiastical matters (excluding marriage) 122 (26%) 161 (14%) 283 (18%) 4. Sexual misconduct 25 (5%) 96 (8%) 121 (7.5%) 5. Difficulties pertaining to marriage 22 (5%) 47 (4%) 69 (4%) Miscellaneous 16 (3%) 24 (2%) 40 (2.5%) TOTAL 480 (100%) 1,144 (100%) 1,624 (100%) 
Source: Adapted from Raymond A. Mentzer, “Disciplina nervus ecclesiae: The Calvinist Reform of Morals at Nîmes,” The Sixteenth Century Journal, Vol. 18, No. 1, Spring 1987.
content.question: Which of the following best describes an overall trend in the data?

choices.label: Disputes and quarrels made up approximately half of offenses in both periods, while the percentage of behavioral and ecclesiastical offenses changed significantly.
Disputes and quarrels made up approximately half of offenses in both periods, while the other categories of offenses also showed little change.
Marriage and sexual misconduct offenses remained a majority of the recorded offenses in both periods.
Overall, the number of offenses decreased significantly from the first period to the second period.

content.answer: Disputes and quarrels made up approximately half of offenses in both periods, while the percentage of behavioral and ecclesiastical offenses changed significantly.
